videoTitle: Cracking the DevOps Code: Courses & Certifications for Success
videoDescription:
Take the courses mentioned here, get certifications and do not forget to add these using our AI-Powered Resume Builder (https://pro.kudoswall.com)
Certifications for Employed DevOps Professionals:
AWS Certified DevOps Engineer: This certification from Amazon Web Services (AWS) validates your expertise in deploying, operating, and managing applications on the AWS platform.
Azure DevOps Engineer: Offered by Microsoft, this certification demonstrates your skills in designing and implementing DevOps practices using Azure technologies.
Google Cloud Professional DevOps Engineer: This certification focuses on designing, developing, and managing DevOps practices on the Google Cloud Platform.
Certified Kubernetes Administrator (CKA): Certified by the Cloud Native Computing Foundation (CNCF), CKA validates your Kubernetes skills, which are crucial for container orchestration.
Certified Jenkins Engineer: Offered by CloudBees, this certification recognizes your proficiency in using Jenkins for continuous integration and continuous delivery (CI/CD) pipelines.
Red Hat Certified Engineer in DevOps: This certification from Red Hat validates your skills in using Red Hat technologies for automating, managing, and optimizing DevOps processes.

Courses for Aspiring DevOps Engineers:
Introduction to DevOps Practices: Online platforms like Coursera, edX, and Udemy offer various introductory courses that cover the fundamental concepts and practices of DevOps.
Docker and Kubernetes Courses: Understanding containerization and orchestration tools like Docker and Kubernetes is essential. There are numerous courses available for beginners and advanced users.
Cloud Platform Courses (AWS, Azure, GCP): Learning the basics of cloud platforms and their DevOps-related services is crucial. Many platforms offer free and paid courses for beginners.
CI/CD Pipeline Courses: Courses on continuous integration and continuous delivery tools like Jenkins, GitLab CI/CD, and CircleCI are essential for automating software delivery.
Infrastructure as Code (IaC) Courses: Learning tools like Terraform and Ansible for automating infrastructure deployment is key for DevOps engineers.
Monitoring and Logging Courses: Understanding tools like Prometheus, Grafana, and ELK Stack (Elasticsearch, Logstash, Kibana) for monitoring and logging is vital.
Scripting and Programming Courses: Proficiency in scripting languages like Python and programming languages like Java can enhance your DevOps skills.
Security and Compliance Courses: DevOps engineers should also be well-versed in security practices. Courses on DevSecOps and security automation can be beneficial.
#DevOpsIndia #Certifications #Courses #TechSkills #CareerGrowth #Cloud #Automation

videoTitle: Matthew Skelton - DevOps Topologies 10 years on: what have we learned about silos, collaboration...
videoDescription:
In this talk, Matthew Skelton - CEO at Conflux and co-author of the book Team Topologies - explores the key learnings from 10 years of Team Topologies and State of DevOps Reports and outlines key steps that organizations can take to improve IT delivery performance:

Organize for flow
Address team cognitive load
Estimate the cost of “tangled software”
Use the Accelerate metrics and community techniques to find good boundaries for flow
Develop secure foundations in social and technical practices that support fast flow
Take a realistic view about the nature and scale of change needed
By combining learnings from State of DevOps Reports and Team Topologies together with principles championed by the DevOps community, organizations can navigate a route to business agility via a fast flow operating model.

videoTitle: Create Managed Azure DevOps Pools with Terraform
videoDescription:
Today we're working with Azure Pipelines and exploring the different options you have when working with agent pools. The main focus will be on the new Azure Managed DevOps Agent Pools, what they are, how they work, and why you might want to use them.

We’ll start by deploying some prerequisites using Terraform, including a virtual network to host our agents. You’ll see how to use the AzAPI provider to get the job done and I’ll walk you through it all, step by step, as we build this Terraform project from scratch.

Once everything is up and running, we’ll connect our agent to an Azure Pipeline and run a deployment to test it out.

If you’re looking to automate Azure DevOps agent pool provisioning with Terraform and AzAPI, or just want to learn more about CI/CD in Azure, you’re in the right place. Hope you enjoy the video!

videoTitle: Manage & Secure Kubernetes Cluster Policies via OPA Gatekeeper. #opa #devops #gatekeeper
videoDescription:
Manage & Secure Kubernetes Cluster Policies via OPA Gatekeeper. #opa #devops #gatekeepers 

Timestamps:

Theory/Concepts : 00:00
Hands on/Practical : 09:00

github repo : https://github.com/RohanRusta21/opa-gatekeeper.git

Concepts :

OPA Gatekeeper: Policy and Governance for Kubernetes

What is OPA:

The Open Policy Agent (OPA) is an open-source, general-purpose policy engine that unifies policy enforcement across the stack. OPA provides a high-level declarative language that lets us specify policies as code and simple APIs to offload policy decision-making from our software. We can use OPA to enforce policies in microservices, Kubernetes, CI/CD pipelines, API gateways, and more. 
In kubernetes, OPA uses admission controllers.

What is OPA Gatekeeper?

OPA Gatekeeper is a specialized project providing first-class integration between OPA and Kubernetes.
OPA Gatekeeper adds the following on top of plain OPA:
● An extensible, parameterized policy library.
● Native Kubernetes CRDs for instantiating the policy library (aka “constraints”).
● Native Kubernetes CRDs for extending the policy library (aka “constraint templates”).
● Audit functionality.

Why you need Gatekeeper?

As a Platform DevOps engineer managing multiple Kubernetes clusters for various projects, you face challenges when users deploy applications without adhering to best practices. Key issues include:
  1.     Lack of ownership unless users apply labels themselves.
  2.     No resource limits, leading to high costs.
  3.     Untrusted images impacting other applications.
  4.     Security and best practice violations across clusters.

To address these, we need governance to enforce limits and rules via policies. OPA Gatekeeper can be configured to implement these policies, ensuring best practices are followed.

videoTitle: What is Git? How would you define Git? || #GitHub #GitLab #BitBucket #DevOps #Git #Python #Java
videoDescription:
What is Git?

How would you define Git?

Well, Git is a distributed version control system, which means two things:

1. It's distributed so people around the world can share code
2. It does version control

So, with version control, you can take snapshots of the state of your current code and maintain a history.

Branching is really the third thing. Git branches allow developers to do isolated development and take chances without messing up the main branch.

So when someone asks me 'What is Git?', that is how I typically respond.

videoTitle: What's the goal of Platform Engineering? #shorts #devops #platformengineering
videoDescription:
Watch the full video: https://youtu.be/JAblex0uS4k

What’s the goal of Platform Engineering? Platform Engineering focusses on the building the infrastructure and the systems that are needed for running your applications and supporting your application throughout the software life cycle. So,  the goal  is to support the developers in the organisation and treat them as customers. That’s why we have in platform engineering the concept of IDP Internal developer platform.
 
So, this platform is treated as an actual product and the customers of the product are the developers.
What is the role of the IDP?
It is to create a thin layer on top of the toolchain that is used inside the organisation to standardise the processes and help developers to have one way to deploy into production

videoTitle: What Does A DevOps Engineer Do? #salesforcetestingguy  ft. @TrainWithShubham
videoDescription:
A DevOps engineer serves as a pivotal link between development and operations teams, fostering seamless collaboration and communication to optimize the software delivery lifecycle.

At the core of a DevOps engineer's role is the establishment and maintenance of CI/CD pipelines, ensuring the continuous integration and deployment of software updates. This accelerates the release of new features and fixes, ultimately reducing the time required for delivering impactful changes.

In summary, the collaborative efforts and automation prowess of a DevOps engineer create an environment conducive to rapid and high-quality software delivery, empowering organizations to stay competitive in the dynamic landscape of software development.

videoTitle: Git Plumbing vs Porcelain #Git #GitHub #GitLab #BitBucket #DevOps #GitOps #Python #Java #JavaScript
videoDescription:
Have you heart the terms Git plumbing and Git Porcelain?

Ever wondered what the different between Git porcelain vs plumbing was?

For the most part, the porcelain is the most commonly used Git files such as:

- git init
- git add
- git commit
- git revert
- git merge
- git rebase
- git reset

That's the Git porcelain, and you won't get your hands too dirty when you touch it.

The Git plumbing? That's typically the config stuff in the hidden .git folder, including things like:

- Refspec
-Packfiles
- The HEAD Pointer
- Git References
- Remote References
- Transfer Protocols
- Garbage Collector
- Recovery files
- Tree Objects
- Environment variables

Hopefully you don't have to get your hands dirty with the Git plumbing too often. It's nice to stick with the Git porcelain.

But at the same time, plumbers do make a lot of money!

videoTitle: Docker Volumes Explained | Docker Hands-on | DevOps in Telugu
videoDescription:
Docker volumes are essential tools for managing persistent data in Docker containers. Unlike container file systems, which are ephemeral and can be deleted when a container stops, volumes provide a way to save data independently from the lifecycle of containers.

When you create a Docker volume, you're essentially setting up a dedicated storage space that can be shared among multiple containers. This is crucial for applications like databases where data integrity needs to be maintained even if the database container crashes or is updated.

In this tutorial about Docker volumes, we will delve into various concepts such as how to create and manage these volumes using Docker commands and Docker Compose. You'll learn how to mount volumes into your containers, enabling them to access stored data seamlessly.

Additionally, we'll explore different types of Docker volumes and their specific uses—such as named volumes and bind mounts. Understanding these distinctions will enhance your ability to manage data effectively within your applications.

If you're new to Docker, this comprehensive guide will help you grasp the foundational principles of volume management while providing practical docker in Telugu for better understanding. Whether you're looking at persistent storage options or just trying to understand what Docker is all about, mastering docker volumes is a fundamental step. 

Join us as we navigate through the essentials of using Docker volumes, ensuring your applications have reliable access to necessary data without complications!

videoDescription:

Don't forget to like, share, and subscribe! Hit the bell icon to stay updated with our latest videos.

For Interview related training please feel free to reach us over the call 9845421738 to discuss further.

I am gonna tell you what DevOps engineers do in less than a minute with an example.

In a restaurant kitchen, there are chefs and wait staff.

Chefs are responsible for creating and experimenting with new dishes. Their job includes coming up with innovative recipes, testing them, and adding the successful ones to the menu. At the same time, they also prepare food to meet the regular demand of customers who visit the restaurant daily. This dual responsibility of innovation and ongoing service can become overwhelming, especially during busy hours when the kitchen is already at full capacity.

Wait staff, on the other hand, focus on delivering the prepared food to customers. Their primary role is to ensure that the food reaches the diners promptly and in perfect condition, keeping the restaurant’s operations running smoothly.

Experimenting with a new dish during peak hours, however, becomes a significant challenge. The process of testing new recipes while maintaining the flow of regular orders often leads to disruptions in the kitchen, causing delays and dissatisfaction among customers.

To address this, the restaurant hires a kitchen manager. The kitchen manager creates a separate small kitchen dedicated to experimenting with new dishes. This ensures that the chefs can focus on their innovations without interfering with the ongoing operations. Once a dish is perfected, the kitchen manager introduces automation, such as using a conveyor belt, to streamline the cooking process. This allows the new dish to be produced efficiently alongside the existing menu items while ensuring there are no interruptions in serving food to the restaurant's customers.

Yes, DevOps engineers are none other than automation experts.

videoTitle: SBOM & Security Scanning in CI/CD | Secure Your DevOps Pipeline with GitHub Actions
videoDescription:
🚀 SBOM & Security Scanning in CI/CD | Secure Your DevOps Pipeline with GitHub Actions 🔒

In this video, we take CI/CD security to the next level by integrating SBOM (Software Bill of Materials) generation and advanced security scanning into your GitHub Actions workflow. If you're only scanning container images for vulnerabilities, you're missing hidden risks! 😱

We’ll cover:
✅ What is SBOM & Why You Need It? 📜
✅ How to Generate an SBOM with Syft 🔍
✅ Scanning Dependencies for Vulnerabilities with Grype 🚨
✅ Performing Full Security Scans with Trivy 🛡
✅ Step-by-Step CI/CD Implementation using GitHub Actions

By the end of this video, you'll have an automated security pipeline that ensures complete supply chain security in your CI/CD workflows! 🔥

🔄 Hands-on Demo:
We'll walk through a real-world GitHub Actions pipeline that:
🔹 Generates an SBOM with Syft
🔹 Scans dependencies with Grype
🔹 Conducts a deep security scan on container images with Trivy
🔹 Automates security checks in every code push & pull request

🖥️ Watch as we push a change to GitHub and trigger an automated security scan in real-time!

🔹 What’s Next?
In our next video, we’ll bring everything together into a complete DevSecOps pipeline using GitHub Actions! 🚀

videoTitle: Practical DevOps: Continuous Delivery vs Continuous Deployment
videoDescription:
Continuous integration, deployment, and delivery are like vectors with the same direction but different magnitudes. Their goal is the same: to make our software development and release process faster and more robust.

The key difference between the three is in the scope of automation applied. What confuses people new to the field is that they are not mutually exclusive, but include each other, like Russian dolls.

5:14 Benefits of Continuous Deployment
6:24 Key takeaways
7:05 Conclusion

videoTitle: Hello World – DevOps Breakdown Song | Screams, Bugs & Git Crimes
videoDescription:
🧠 FOR DEVELOPERS, BY A DEVELOPER WHO LOST HIS MIND 🧠

- Git reset hard scream therapy
- Whispers about 2AM logic failures
- Stand-up style rants about Agile lies
- Barbershop meets burnout
- Kevin... just Kevin.

Lyrics
=====
(Intro)
hello... heLLo... HELLO WORLD?  
Can anybody hear me behind the firewall...?  
404 soul not found...

(Verse 1) 
Push to prod at 3 A.M.,  
Brain’s a loop in mayhem,  
Told myself “just one more line,”  
Now it’s been seven sprints of crime.  

GIT RESET --HARD!!

Don’t forget to update your dependencies...  
You wrote that logic at 2 A.M... it's trash...  
Kevin force-pushed again...

You ever deploy a microservice and pray it doesn’t become a macro-disaster?  
My Docker container’s the only thing holding me together.  
I tried therapy once... then Jira assigned me 14 more tickets.  
My manager said: “Just estimate in story points.”  
I said: haa

(Chorus)
Hello world, hello pain,  
Is this loop recursive or am I insane?  
From Python dreams to Java screams,  
My RAM is low... and so are my hopes.

Agile... agile... agile...  
Deliverable... agile...

(Verse 2) 
Null pointer stabbed me in the back,  
Kubernetes launched a DDoS attack.  
Stack Overflow won’t answer me,  
Even GPT said: “Yo bro, I’d flee.”

BUILD FAILED!!!

(Bridge)
One commit to rule them all...  
One Slack ping begins my fall...  
You're on-call this weekend... forever...

Did you test it?  
It works on my machine!  
Kevin deleted the prod DB!  
Why is prod even accessible from the dashboard?!  
HugOps... HugOps... HugOps...

How did I become this...?  
I just wanted to build an app that makes cat noises...

(Final Chorus)
Ohhhh HELLO WOOORLD, my sanity’s gone,  
These tickets keep respawning at dawn.  
Manager says we’re agile and fast,  
But this sprint’s a dumpster fire blast.

NOT ON PROOOOOOD!!

videoTitle: Stop using Read-Host and do this instead #powershell  #devops  #scripting
videoDescription:
Stop using Read-Host and do this instead:

Read-Host has limitations. 

- You cannot pass information to it 
- You cannot validate what the user provided
- It always stops the script

There is a better way - use parameters instead.

- Control the type of input
- Make it mandatory or optional
- Pass argument from the command line
- or prompt the user to provide an argument, when required and not passed

In this short video, I'll show you how to implement simple parameters and how to use them.

Would you like to learn more about the parameters?

videoTitle: DevOps Explained with a Restaurant Analogy | DevOps Tutorial
videoDescription:
In this DevOps tutorial, we explain what DevOps is using a restaurant analogy. Perfect for beginners in DevOps or aspiring DevOps engineers!

**DevOps Explained with a Restaurant Analogy | DevOps Tutorial**

Have you ever wondered what **DevOps** really means and why it’s so important in today’s tech world? 🤔 Don’t worry — in this video, we’ll explain **DevOps in the simplest way possible** using a **fun restaurant analogy** that anyone can understand! 🍽️

Just like a restaurant kitchen and service team must work together to serve customers efficiently, **DevOps brings Development and Operations together** to deliver software faster, more reliably, and with fewer issues.

In this **beginner-friendly DevOps tutorial**, you’ll learn:
✅ What DevOps really is and why companies use it
✅ How DevOps improves **collaboration between developers and operations teams**
✅ The key principles of DevOps – **automation, CI/CD, monitoring, and feedback loops**
✅ How the **restaurant analogy** makes DevOps easy to understand
✅ Real-world benefits of DevOps in **software delivery and business success**

By the end of this video, you’ll have a **clear understanding of DevOps** and why it’s a game-changer in modern **software development and IT operations**.

videoTitle: The VSM Renaissance: Catalysed by DevOps | Helen Beal
videoDescription:
#DevOps has enabled digital transformation. In fifteen years, the way we engineer software has revolutionized. It’s spread Continuous Integration and delivery across the globe, humanized IT culture, automated toil, and paying down technical debt. But it’s nowhere near done. A lot of organizations have hit the ceiling. A wall. The brakes. Stagnated. The promise remains: We can thrive in the digital age, create joy through customer experiences, move fast, be nimble, outcompete, and achieve extraordinary organizational performance. But it needs unlocking. #ValueStreamManagement has hundreds of years of history, but its time is now. Building on everything we’ve learned from DevOps, using the toolchains, pipelines, and rich data sources we’ve created, combining VSM and DevOps means we can see organizations as value-generating enterprises. We can pinpoint the choke points, bottlenecks, and dependencies and quickly apply fixes to optimize flow and value realization.

In this talk, Helen Beal will share real stories from enterprises she’s worked with on how they’ve relentlessly pursued improvement using VSM and DevOps practices and the outcomes they’ve seen.

----

About the speaker:

Helen Beal is CEO and Chair of the Value Stream Management Consortium and co-chair of the OASIS Value Stream Management Interoperability Technical Committee. She leads the ambassador program at PeopleCert for the DevOps Institute, ITIL, and PRINCE2. She is also Chair of the DevNetwork DevOps Advisory Board and provides strategic advisory services to DevOps and VSM industry leaders.

Helen authorizes the VSMC's annual State of VSM Reports and Moogsoft's State of Availability Report. She is also a co-author of Investments Unlimited, a book about DevOps and governance published by IT Revolution. She is a DevOps editor for InfoQ and writes for many other online platforms.

Helen hosts the Day-to-Day DevOps webinar series for BrightTalk and speaks on DevOps, AI, and value stream-related topics at industry conferences and corporate events.

She regularly appears in TechBeacon’s DevOps Top100 lists, was recognized as the Top DevOps Evangelist 2020 in the DevOps Dozen awards, and was a finalist for Computing DevOps Excellence Awards’ DevOps Professional of the Year 2021.

She serves on advisory and judging boards for many initiatives, including Developer Week, DevOps World, JAX DevOps, and InterOp.

videoTitle: Automating license enforcement in your CI/CD pipeline and trends in DevOps with Eli Birger
videoDescription:
Eli's talk at DevOpsDays Raleigh focused on automating license checks in CI/CD pipelines. Of course, the topic of open source licenses is fascinating to the All Things Open community and we wanted to learn more. During this interview, we talked with Eli about the importance of open source licensing, in particular, how they are automating license enforcement. Then we discussed some trends in DevOps from the perspective of a former DevOps engineer and manager.

Registration for All Things Open 2024 is now open. Register now to save your spot: https://allthingsopen.org/ato-registration-now-open

0:00 - Introduction
0:08 - Welcome Eli Birger
0:40 - Tell us about yourself
2:10 - Can you share a few key takeaways that you shared with the audience here? 
3:28 - Why are open source licenses important?
4:16 - What's happening in DevOps, a topic, a trend, a debate, that people should be aware of?
5:09 - What's one piece of advice that you want to share with the All Things Open community?

Key takeaways:
* We publicly share  the CI/CD enforcement we built for different types of licenses
* The topic of open source licenses is very complex and very boring
* The volume of licenses complicates the space
* Be aware of "blind spots" in your processes and methodology
* Do not take things for granted and challenge everything
* Invest at least one hour a day for learning and challenging things

###
About Eli Birger 
Eli is a passionate technologist with a background in telecom, cyber, and storage. He has over six years of experience as a DevOps Manager, where he specialized in building large-scale SaaS systems based on Kubernetes. As the CTO at PerfectScales, his current focus is on building solutions that solve the pains of operating highly-disturbed Kubernetes systems, keeping them running both efficiently and resiliently.

About All Things Open
All Things Open is a universe of open source events and platforms designed to educate and connect technologists around the world. It includes the All Things Open conference, the largest open source / tech / web event on the U.S. East Coast, meetups in the Research Triangle Park (RTP) of NC, South Carolina, and New York City, and a YouTube channel with more than 1,000 free recordings. See everything we do at https://allthingsopen.org.

Join our meetups:
* New York City meetup: https://www.meetup.com/Open-Source-NYC/
* South Carolina meetup: https://www.meetup.com/open-source-south-carolina/
* Research Triangle Park, NC meetup: https://www.meetup.com/all-things-open-rtp-meetup/

videoTitle: Accelerate DevOps Artifact Delivery of Docker images, NPM & Debian packages with Varnish
videoDescription:
Modern organizations rely on external dependencies for software development, testing, and delivery. Fast artifact delivery is critical to DevOps workflows—any delay can slow deployments and impact developer productivity.

But by offloading CI/CD system pressure and positioning caches closer to developers, you can reduce network latency, minimize wait times, and improve overall efficiency. 

In this webinar, we’ll demonstrate how to accelerate DevOps artifact delivery by caching key assets like Docker images, Debian packages, and NPM libraries using Varnish Enterprise, a leading caching and data acceleration platform.

Join us for a hands-on session featuring real-world examples across various artifact management platforms, demonstrating how Varnish optimizes artifact delivery and enhances Quality of Service in diverse DevOps environments.

Whether the code is initially deployed or re-deployment of codebase such as the webservice project is performed, then the Build and Deployment pipelines are triggered and the below mentioned configured tests/validations are performed and the code is promoted to the higher environment.

  1. Unit Testing

videoDescription:
Autoscaling is a game-changer in cloud computing, allowing you to dynamically adjust computational resources based on the load on your server farm. videoTitle: Emmanuel Ahaiwe - Balancing Technical Debt and Modernisation in DevOps
videoDescription:
This talk explains a balanced approach for a successful migration. A thorough understanding of the quirks of legacy applications is the foundation for a successful migration to more modern infrastructure in DevOps. However, this understanding cuts across various teams, not just the DevOps or SRE team. The security team has to perform a risk assessment, observability has to be in place by the SRE team, infrastructure compatibility, incremental migration strategy, Quality Assurance team needs to perform tests, and Documentation also has to be taken into account. Stakeholders - internal and external ones need to be carried along to manage expectations.

The approach of working across various teams ensures that all aspects of the migration process are addressed comprehensively, minimising risks and maximising the chances of success. Each team brings its expertise and perspective to the table, contributing to a well-rounded migration strategy. By involving all relevant teams and stakeholders from the outset, potential issues can be identified and addressed early on, leading to a smoother and more efficient migration process.

At Shoreline, we are creating GPT-powered runbooks to alleviate some of the challenges that come with being on call.

Being on call is like becoming an expert on everything that might go wrong, which is impossible. 

That's why our runbooks cover a wide range of scenarios to help engineers deal with:

videoTitle: Evolving teams beyond DevOps | Johan Abildskov | Uber
videoDescription:
At The Future of Software conference in London, Johan Abildskov covered some of the troubles that come from the disconnect between how we perceive making software and what reality shows us, emphasizing concrete examples and practices.

In his talk, Johan highlights various topics that all software development teams should be aware of, including playfulness as a mindset and psychological safety vs. high performance.

----

About the speaker:

Johan is a Software Engineer at Uber. Johan helps build Odin, the stateful orchestration platform - part of the infrastructure that helps Uber serve more than 1M trips per hour every day. Before becoming a Software Engineer, Johan spent a few years as a DevOps and Continuous Delivery consultant, gathering experience across the industry.

----

videoTitle: AI-Powered DevOps Analytics Slashes Software Delivery Time | AppDevANGLE
videoDescription:
Can AI unlock faster, smarter software delivery? In this episode of AppDevANGLE, Paul Nashawaty, Principal Analyst at theCUBE Research, sits down with Naveen Kumar, Founder and CEO of Truxt.ai, to explore how artificial intelligence is reshaping DevOps analytics, software development lifecycles (SDLC), and business decision-making at scale.
According to theCUBE Research, organizations that embed AI into their analytics workflows are twice as likely to report significant value from their data initiatives. Truxt.ai is built to capitalize on that insight by automating analysis, surfacing actionable DevOps intelligence, and closing the feedback loop between development and business KPIs.
In this episode, you’ll learn:
Why DORA metrics aren’t enough—and how Truxt.ai uncovers the why, not just the what


How to use agentic AI to reduce reliance on manual analysis and accelerate decision-making


How to streamline CI/CD pipelines and standardize toolchains across large enterprises


Why AI improves DevOps consistency and maturity across teams and business units


How organizations can go from quarterly releases to hourly software delivery


Practical strategies to reduce lead time for changes, improve MTTR, and drive business outcomes
“Knowing your deployment frequency isn’t enough. AI shows you why it’s happening—and how to fix it.” — Naveen, CEO of Truxt.ai
Key Topics Covered:
DevOps maturity and adoption barriers


DORA vs SPACE vs real-world bottlenecks


AI integration across GitHub, Jira, Jenkins, and more


How AI elevates software delivery from metrics to insights


Reducing complexity from 6–15 DevOps tools down to actionable recommendations


Business impact: faster releases, better margins, improved go-to-market speed
Industry Insight:
Only 8% of organizations can deploy code hourly, yet 24% want to. AI-powered analytics like Truxt.ai can help close this gap.

00:06 - Unveiling Truxt.ai: Integrating AI for Enhanced Decision Making
02:31 - Navigating and Enhancing DevOps Performance
05:13 - Streamlining Innovation: Accelerating Development and Standardization Across Enterprises
08:30 - Embracing the Future: DevOps, AI, and Community Engagement

videoTitle: Service Mesh vs. Data Mesh Explained #devops #microservices #servicemesh #datamesh #techtalk

The journey from traditional monolithic architectures to microservices has brought unparalleled flexibility and innovation. But it also introduced a new layer of complexity. This is where service meshes shine by providing the backbone for secure, efficient, and observable inter-service communication.
Meanwhile, data meshes revolutionize data ownership and governance by ensuring each data product is managed with care and precision.

videoTitle: DevOps Lifecycle Simplified: The Car Analogy — Full Beginner Tutorial
videoDescription:
In this beginner tutorial, we simplify the DevOps lifecycle using a car analogy. Learn the basics of DevOps and its stages in an easy-to-understand way!

🚗 **DevOps Lifecycle Simplified: The Car Analogy — Full Beginner Tutorial** ⚙️

This is a **full beginner-friendly DevOps tutorial**, designed to break down the **lifecycle stages of DevOps** in **plain English**, without overwhelming jargon.

✨ **Inside this video, you’ll learn:**

✅ Simple explanations of tools like **Git, Jenkins, Docker, Kubernetes**, and **CI/CD pipelines**
✅ How DevOps speeds up delivery, improves teamwork, and reduces errors — explained with a relatable **real-life example**

videoTitle: Cold Starts Explained: The Hidden Challenge of Serverless Computing #serverlesscomputing #devops
videoDescription:
In a serverless environment, functions run on-demand as a response to a triggered event, like a user request. Since the initialization of a function instance takes some time, this approach causes what we call startup latency and “cold starts.”

The startup latency can vary significantly — it may range from a few milliseconds to several seconds and it depends on different factors — many of them under the developer’s control.

videoTitle: DevOpsDays Seattle 2022: Continuous Improvement: DevOps and Mental Health by Aaron Aldrich
videoDescription:
Dealing with any neuro-diversity is difficult and stigmatized, but lessons learned from DevOps and Complex Systems management have helped me improve how I handle situations. These lessons can be applied broadly and shift our thinking to how DevOps extends beyond tech alone. Mental illness is stigmatized and hard to talk about publicly. Doubly so in the tech industry where we assign much of our personal value to our brains. I want to share my struggles with mental health and the lessons I’ve learned from Systems operation and DevOps that have helped me get by and frame my struggle in a manageable way.

I want to start a conversation to:

    Help reduce the stigma of Mental Illness by talking about it
    Provide some illustration of things that have helped me, so hopefully they can help you
    Show how the concepts of DevOps have application reaching beyond High Technology
    Spark further conversation about Mental health in tech
    Hopefully provide a new group and community for those for whom mental health is a concern

Apply principles of targeted monitoring to training

videoTitle: DevOps Lifecycle Simplified: The Restaurant Analogy — Full Beginner Tutorial
videoDescription:
In this beginner-friendly tutorial, we simplify the DevOps lifecycle using a restaurant analogy. Learn why DevOps is important and how it can streamline your development process!

🍽️ **DevOps Lifecycle Simplified: The Restaurant Analogy — Full Beginner Tutorial** ⚙️

Have you ever wondered what the **DevOps Lifecycle** really means but found it too technical? In this **beginner-friendly DevOps tutorial**, we’ll explain DevOps using a **restaurant analogy** — making it super easy to understand, even if you have no technical background.

Think of DevOps like running a restaurant: from planning the menu to cooking, serving customers, and constantly improving. In the same way, DevOps is about **planning, coding, building, testing, releasing, deploying, operating, and monitoring** software in a smooth cycle.

✨ **Inside this video, you’ll learn:**
✅ What the **DevOps Lifecycle** is and why it matters
✅ The **7 stages of DevOps** explained step by step with a restaurant example
✅ How chefs (developers) and waiters (operations) work together just like **Dev + Ops** teams
✅ Real-world beginner-friendly explanations of **CI/CD pipelines, automation, and popular tools** (Git, Jenkins, Docker, Kubernetes)
✅ Why DevOps helps deliver **faster, better, and more reliable results**
✅ How to remember DevOps easily with the restaurant analogy

This is a **full-length DevOps tutorial** created for **absolute beginners, students, and aspiring DevOps engineers**. No jargon, just clear explanations!

videoTitle: Ansible Automated Security Hardening | Step-by-Step Hands-On Lab for DevOps & Cloud Engineers
videoDescription:
Accelerate your infrastructure security with this hands-on lab! In this step-by-step tutorial, Karthik Sekar demonstrates how to automate server security hardening using Ansible playbooks. Whether you’re a DevOps engineer, cloud architect, or IT professional, you’ll learn how to deploy, configure, and audit security best practices—consistently and at scale.

👩‍💻What you’ll learn:
- Why automated security hardening is critical for compliance and robust defence
- When and where to deploy Ansible-based security automation in real environments
- Prerequisites and setup: Control machine, SSH configuration, hosts inventory, and privileges
- Full implementation: Creating and running an Ansible playbook to remove insecure packages, install and configure firewalls, and enforce best practices
Step-by-step execution and verification across multiple servers
- Auditing and documentation for compliance

🔧 Lab Outline:
- Overview: Why and when to automate security hardening
- Prerequisites and lab setup
- Writing the security-hardening.yml playbook (with real examples)
- Defining inventory (hosts file) for production servers
- Running the playbook and verifying changes
- Audit techniques for compliance and reporting
- Pros & cons, troubleshooting, and tips for scaling

videoTitle: DevOps Lifecycle Explained: Essential Tools for Beginners | DevOps Tutorial
videoDescription:
Learn the essential tools for beginners in this DevOps tutorial! Understand the DevOps lifecycle and get started with DevOps basics today.

⚙️ **DevOps Lifecycle Explained: Essential Tools for Beginners | DevOps Tutorial** 🚀

Are you just starting your **DevOps journey** and want to understand both the **DevOps lifecycle** and the **essential tools** that power it? This **beginner-friendly DevOps tutorial** explains everything step by step in **plain English** so you can quickly build a solid foundation.

The **DevOps lifecycle** has several stages, and each stage uses different tools to make software development and delivery faster, smoother, and more reliable. In this full-length guide, you’ll learn not just the concepts but also the **tools beginners should know** to get hands-on with DevOps.

✨ **Inside this video, you’ll learn:**
✅ What the **DevOps Lifecycle** is and why it matters

✅ Beginner-friendly explanations of **essential DevOps tools** like:

* **Git & GitHub** (Version Control)
* **Jenkins** (Continuous Integration)
* **Docker** (Containerization)
* **Kubernetes** (Container Orchestration)
* **Ansible / Terraform** (Infrastructure as Code)
* **Prometheus & Grafana** (Monitoring)
  ✅ How these tools fit into the DevOps lifecycle
  ✅ Why learning DevOps is a must for **IT beginners, students, and future engineers**

This is a **complete DevOps tutorial for beginners** — no jargon, no confusion, just a clear and engaging guide that helps you understand the **lifecycle + tools** step by step.

videoTitle: CHAOS thought experiments, meetups, and more with developer advocate Laura Santamaria #DevOps
videoDescription:
Laura Santamaria is a lead developer advocate at Dell Technologies. She loves to learn and explain how things work to bridge the gaps in engineering disciplines. Laura sat down with the All Things Open team at DevOpsDays Raleigh to talk about DevOps and system science, organizational change, and learning through meetups and events.

0:00 - Introduction
0:08 - Welcome Laura Santamaria
0:58 - Can you share a few key takeaways that you shared with the audience here? 
2:40 - What's happening in DevOps, a topic, a trend, a debate, that people should be aware of?
4:30 - What's one piece of advice that you want to share with the All Things Open community?
5:40 - How can people find you on the socials?

Key takeaways
* if you want to make a transformation stick, if you want to bring changes to your company and make sure that it continues past day one or day zero, you're looking at how to ensure equilibrium across multiple systems within your company.

* The best way to ensure that your change sticks in an organization is to think through a CHAOS thought experiment.

* I think that a lot of people believe that DevOps is old-fashioned and it's kind of not really relevant anymore, but they don't understand that it's not about the tools. It's not about these processes that a lot of people have implemented over time. It's really about the people and about the changes you're trying to make over this course of time.

* Join your local meetup. If you can't find one, make one. It's completely okay to have multiple meetups in a city, but bring them all back because that's really where we learn.


###

About All Things Open
All Things Open is a universe of open source events and platforms designed to educate and connect technologists around the world. It includes the All Things Open conference, the largest open source / tech / web event on the U.S. East Coast, meetups in the Research Triangle Park (RTP) of NC, South Carolina, and New York City, and a YouTube channel with more than 1,000 free recordings. videoTitle: Continuous Delivery is just 10% about automation ... #devops #development #webdevelopment
videoDescription:
Continuous Delivery is just 10% about tools ...


And 90% about how we work, the relationships, and our practices as a team and company.

That was a core topic of our one-hour-long discussion about "What is Continuous Delivery" I had with Bryan Finster.

We met because of the misconceptions we see out there.

𝗪𝗵𝗮𝘁 𝗜 𝘀𝗲𝗲 𝗾𝘂𝗶𝘁𝗲 𝗼𝗳𝘁𝗲𝗻:
• CD is the automation part of CI/CD
• Automation (CD) isn't the silver bullet 


𝗢𝘁𝗵𝗲𝗿 𝗺𝗶𝘀𝗰𝗼𝗻𝗰𝗲𝗽𝘁𝗶𝗼𝗻𝘀 𝘄𝗲 𝗵𝗮𝘃𝗲 𝗰𝗼𝘃𝗲𝗿𝗲𝗱:
• Staging environments are the final place for testing in Continuous Delivery.
• Open-source development is compatible with Continuous Delivery.
• Complicated pipelines and numerous testing tools are necessary.
• Developers should stay isolated and avoid business discussions.
• You need separate testing tools and teams for every type of test.
• Continuous Delivery requires an already high-performing team.
• Deployments should only happen when a feature is fully ready.
• Developers are not capable of testing their own code.
• Continuous Delivery only works for tech companies.
• Engineers should focus on code over outcomes.
• Deploying on Fridays is inherently risky.
• Code freezes improve stability. 😃


𝗪𝗮𝗻𝘁 𝘁𝗼 𝗹𝗶𝘀𝘁𝗲𝗻 𝘁𝗼 𝘁𝗵𝗲 𝗳𝘂𝗹𝗹 𝘃𝗲𝗿𝘀𝗶𝗼𝗻?
Click on my profile for the YouTube, Spotify, and Blog versions.


What's your experience?


Have a great Sunday,
Adrian

videoTitle: Empower Your DevOps with Architecture-Driven IaC & InnerSourcing | Full Office Hours Keynote #07
videoDescription:
In our 7th Office Hours, we introduced key updates designed to make infrastructure management more transparent, scalable, and collaborative. This session focused on how architecture-driven Infrastructure as Code (IaC) and InnerSourcing can transform the way DevOps teams build, share, and manage infrastructure at scale.

Key Takeaways:
InnerSourcing with Custom Terraform Modules – We introduced custom Terraform modules built on InnerSourcing principles, enabling teams to collaborate and contribute to a shared infrastructure codebase. By applying open-source methodologies within an organization, DevOps teams gain flexibility, efficiency, and reusability while reducing silos.

View Permissions in User Management – Security and governance are critical in modern DevOps workflows. This feature allows granular access control, ensuring that only the right people have visibility into specific resources, balancing security with operational efficiency.

The Future of Infrastructure Collaboration – As organizations scale, having a decentralized but structured approach to infrastructure management is key. We discussed how InnerSourcing, Infrastructure as Code (IaC), and DevOps best practices can help teams move faster while maintaining control.

Keywords: DevOps, InnerSourcing, Infrastructure as Code, IaC, Terraform, cloud automation, platform engineering, security and governance, DevOps collaboration, access management, software development

Chapters:

0:00 - Intro
3:15 - InnerSourcing with Custom Terraform Modules
25:21 - View Permissions in User Management
29:46 - Q/A and more


#infrastructuremanagement  #devops  #OfficeHours #Reduceddowntime #securityupdates s #rbac  #ProjectTemplates #ContainerRegistries #cloudnative  #techwebinar

videoDescription:
👋 Welcome to DevOpsFarm Hands-On Training Series!

In today’s session, we dive deeper into Jenkins and its role in automating CI/CD pipelines. From installation to building pipelines, we’ll walk through everything step by step in a hands-on format.

Jenkins setup and configuration
Understanding Organizations & Repositories
CI/CD concepts explained clearly
Jenkins Actions and real-world examples
Interactive Q&A with learners

Introduction & Jenkins Agents

00:00:41 - Using Docker for dynamic agents.
00:01:38 - Jenkins settings, tools, and plugins.
00:02:06 - Restarting Jenkins after plugin installation.

Pipelines and Docker

00:03:18 - Confirming pipeline jobs and working with Docker.

Jenkins Credentials & Security

Dynamic Agents & Security Checks

01:31:59 - Running a security check on the app.

videoTitle: New 📚 Release! Architecting and Implementing DevOps for Infrastructure Management in Azure #books
videoDescription:
New 📚 Release! Architecting and Implementing DevOps for Infrastructure Management in Azure: Infrastructure DevOps in Azure: Configure, Deploy, & Automate Your Azure resources with terraform, GitHub Actions and Ansible by Ashish Raj

Embark on a transformative journey from basic to intricate infrastructure configurations—think high availability, scalability, and security—all through the power of Infrastructure as Code. Dive into the automation of Azure resource deployments, leveraging DevOps tools with comprehensive, step-by-step guidance and practical examples. But the learning doesn't stop at deployment; delve deeper into automated governance and monitoring, ensuring your infrastructure is not just built but also managed with precision and efficiency.

Find it on Leanpub!

#MicrosoftAzure #coding #programming #newreleases #books #bookstan

Link: https://leanpub.com/devopsinazure

About the Book

In the face of accelerated development cycles, Infrastructure teams must align with the culture of rapid deployment and infrastructure versioning. Embracing Infrastructure as Code, Continuous Integration, and Configuration Management practices becomes imperative. Tools like Terraform, GitHub Actions, and Ansible empower infrastructure engineers to implement scalable Infrastructure as Code practices in Azure.

This book serves as a thorough guide for deploying, configuring, and automating Azure infrastructure using DevOps tools. It navigates through cloud architecture patterns with DevOps tools, illustrating their application in Azure solution design. Subsequently, the book delves into the implementation of the architected solution, utilizing DevOps tools like Terraform, GitHub Actions, Packer, Ansible, etc., to address specific architectural requirements with emphasis on scaling the solution architecture and establishing governance, aligning with DevOps principles.

Upon finishing this book, readers will be equipped with the expertise to transform business requirements into Azure-compatible solution architectures, seamlessly incorporating a DevOps approach to deployment. Readers will demonstrate proficiency in executing end-to-end deployment with governance and monitoring proficiently through the consistent application of DevOps tools.

About the Author

Ashish Raj is a technologist and storyteller who helps engineering teams improve their velocity. He believes the biggest challenges facing engineers aren't technical, but not knowing how to tie people, process and technology. With an extensive background spanning innovative startups to leading tech conglomerates, Ashish currently serves as a Cloud & DevOps Architect at Haufe Group.

A fervent advocate and contributor to the DevOps and cloud communities, he shares expertise through webinars and local meetups. Holding Microsoft certifications in DevOps, Architecture, and Certified Microsoft Trainer. Ashish co-founded "AzureTalk," a prominent IM-based global Azure community on Telegram, and initiated "AzureDevOpsPro," a thriving DevOps community. He shares educational cloud and DevOps videos on his YouTube channel, youtube.com/ashishrajsrivastava

Please Subscribe and Follow!

YouTube: https://www.youtube.com/leanpub
Twitter: https://twitter.com/leanpub
Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/leanpub
Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/leanpub

videoTitle: History and Evolution of DevOps | DevOps Explained
videoDescription:
In this video, I take a deep dive into the history and evolution of DevOps, exploring how it emerged as a response to inefficiencies in software delivery and grew into the vital practice it is today. From its origins with Patrick Debois and the first-ever DevOpsDays conference to the rise of tools and cultural shifts, learn how DevOps reshaped the way teams collaborate and deploy software.

Key Takeaways:
- Origins: How DevOps started as a cultural shift, not just a set of tools.
- Evolution: The journey from small startups to large enterprises adopting DevOps practices.
- The Future: The growth of concepts like DevSecOps, GitOps, and AI-driven DevOps.

#itcareer #agilepeople #realtech #technology #devops #devopstraining #devopslife #devopsculture #history

videoTitle: 🚀 Kubernetes Core Concepts: Avoid Deployment Disasters! 🤯 ( Episode 6 )
videoDescription:
Welcome to Episode 6 of our Kubernetes series! In this video, we'll dive into three core Kubernetes concepts that are essential for any developer or DevOps professional: Namespaces, ConfigMaps, and Secrets. By the end of this episode, you'll have a solid understanding of how these tools help you organize, configure, and secure your applications in a Kubernetes environment.

🗺️ Namespaces: Your Key to Organization

Namespaces are a fundamental way to divide your cluster's resources. Think of a namespace as a virtual cluster within your physical Kubernetes cluster. They're designed to help you:

Organize Resources: They prevent naming conflicts when multiple teams or applications use the same cluster. For instance, you could have a development namespace and a production namespace, each with its own nginx-deployment without any conflicts.

Isolate Environments: Namespaces provide a scope for resource names. You can list all the pods in the production namespace, keeping them separate from those in the development namespace.

Enhance Security: By using Role-Based Access Control (RBAC), you can define policies that restrict users or teams to specific namespaces, ensuring they can only interact with the resources they're authorized to access. This is particularly useful in multi-tenant environments.

⚙️ Managing Application Configuration
When deploying applications, you often need to provide configuration data and credentials. Kubernetes offers two primary resources for this: ConfigMaps and Secrets. Understanding the difference is crucial.

1. ConfigMaps: For Non-Sensitive Data
A ConfigMap is an API object used to store non-confidential data in key-value pairs. 🗄️ It's perfect for things like:

Environment variables
Configuration files
Command-line arguments

ConfigMaps decouple your application's configuration from its code, making it easy to change settings without rebuilding your container image. They are stored as plain text, so NEVER use them for sensitive information.

2. Secrets: For Sensitive Data

A Secret is similar to a ConfigMap but is specifically designed to hold sensitive information. The data in a Secret is base64-encoded by default, which is a form of encoding, NOT encryption. 🤫 Secrets are used to store:

Passwords
OAuth tokens
SSH keys

For the highest level of security, consider integrating an external secret management tool like HashiCorp Vault. These tools provide robust encryption, audit logs, and dynamic secrets, offering a much more secure solution than Kubernetes' built-in Secrets.

🎬 Ready to Learn More?
Now that you've got a handle on Namespaces, ConfigMaps, and Secrets, you're ready to start building more organized and secure applications in Kubernetes. Watch our video to see these concepts in action and learn how to implement them in your own projects! Don't forget to like, share, and subscribe for more Kubernetes content. 🚀


#Kubernetes #DevOps #CloudComputing #Containerization #Namespaces #ConfigMaps #Secrets #K8s #KubernetesTutorial #TechTutorial
